moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf: Until here, standard, "book" moves. The two will manouver very slowly seeking for an attack line, in a strategic display.
moves.12. Bf3 Rb8 13. Qd2 Bd7 14. Nb3 b6 15. g: White has to risk some more if he wants an attack line.
moves.15... Bc8: Black has time to relocate his lsb on the big diagonal.
moves.16. g5 Nd7: White's position seems overwhelming, while black is completely stuck on his third rank, pieces all together... normally, a losing scenario, but hey, it's Kasparov behind it. He has everything under control. The deepness of the defence is far beyond my ability to decode it.
moves.17. Qf2: Attacks b6 and, indirectly, f7. And delays the bishop's run to b7.
moves.17... Bf8: Now the other bishop will search for the fianchetto. Very delicate.
moves.18. Bg2 Bb7 19. Rad1 g6 20. Bc1: Is Karpov protecting b2 against a future B(g7)xb2?
moves.20... Rbc8 21. Rd3 Nb4 22. Rh3 Bg7:
Leontxo says white should have played f5 right now. 

23.	f4-f5	e6-f5
24.	e4-f5	b7-g2+
25.	h1-g2	c7-b7+
26.	g2-g1	c8-c4
27.	f5-g6	c4-g4+
28.	h3-g3	g4-g3+
29.	h2-g3	d7-e5
30.	g6-h7+	g8-h8
31.	f2-f5	b4-c2
32.	f5-c2	e5-f3+
33.	f1-f3	b7-f3
34.	c2-f2	f3-d3
moves.23. Be3:
It would be a mistake trying to get the advantage on c3: 

23.	c1-e3	g7-c3
24.	b2-c3	c7-c3
25.	e3-d4	c3-h3
26.	g2-h3	c8-c2
27.	f2-h4	        b7-e4+
28.	h1-g1	d7-f8
moves.23... Re7:
Covering f7. Now, f5 for white doesn't work anymore.

24.	f4-f5	e6-f5
25.	e4-f5	b7-g2+
26.	h1-g2	g7-c3
27.	b2-c3	c7-c3
28.	e3-d4	c3-c2
29.	g2-g1	c2-f2+
30.	f1-f2	e7-e1+
31.	f2-f1	e1-f1+
32.	g1-f1	g6-f5
moves.24. Kg1: White is attacking, but he has some weaknesses he has to take care of.
moves.24... Rce8 25. Rd1 f5: Can you imagine how deep calculations must be performed in order to be able to play this?
moves.26. gxf6 e.p. Nxf6: "Kasparov entrega b6 a cambio de armonía y actividad." says Leontxo: Kasparov gives away b6 seeking for harmony (piece coordination) and activity.
moves.27. Rg3 Rf7 28. Bxb6 Qb8 29. Be3: I won't say ?, but it seems to deserve it. The pawn costed 2 tempoes, and the white's queenside is weak. The white's attack over the black king is not going anywhere, right now.
moves.29... Nh5 30. Rg4 Nf6 31. Rh4: Karpov needs to win, he cannot allow a draw.
moves.31... g5 32. fxg5 Ng4: Better thank Nxe4, according to Leontxo. This move wins the c2 pawn, and eliminate one of the most active white pieces.
moves.33. Qe2 Nxe3 34. Qxe3 Nxc2 35. Qb6: White is now playing against black's central pawns.
moves.35... Ba8:
QxQ, RxQ, Bh3! would have be the right move. Leontxo says Karpos was in time trouble here. 

36.	b6-b8	e8-b8
37.	g2-h3	b8-b3
38.	h3-e6	b3-c3
39.	b2-c3	g7-c3
40.	d1-d6	g8-g7
41.	e6-f7	g7-f7
42.	h4-h7+
moves.36. Rxd6 Rb7 37. Qxa6 Rxb3: 3 pawns for a piece would be nice, but more white pawns will fall.
moves.38. Rxe6 Rxb2 39. Qc4 Kh8 40. e5: Leontxo says this is a mistake. In fact, Rb1+, NxR, QxN+, and white has a hard time defending against multiple threats. But here, the simple Ne3 seems to win.
moves.40... Qa7+ 41. Kh1 Bxg2+ 42. Kxg2 Nd4+: This was actually played. I don't understand why not Ne6++, winning the queen. Maybe is there a mate somewhere.
